[h1] Better Upgrade and 2nd Attempt from Previous Game [/h1] 

Granblue Fantasy Versus Rising is the perfect game for me, and I think itâ€™s great for anyone who wants to play an anime fighter (or fighting game in general) without being overwhelmed by long combos or high execution requirements.

It plays fast without sacrificing clarity. Even though it uses modern fighting game features like auto-combos and special move shortcuts, itâ€™s not dumbed down at all â€” thereâ€™s still plenty of depth.

[h2] Character Roster [/h2] 
Right now there are 38 playable characters, with one more on the way. (Season 3 hasnâ€™t been announced yet, so weâ€™ll see.) Every character feels distinct, so you can easily find an archetype that fits your playstyle. Some characters even come with extra gimmicks that make them stand out more.

[h2] Online Experience [/h2] 
Matchmaking has been fine for me so far. Iâ€™m playing from Indonesia (SEA) with a so-so internet provider, and I can still get stable matches against players from Japan and China. Disclaimer: I use a cable connection â€” and you should too.

The playerbase is still active enough that you can find online matches without long queue times. And since the game has crossplay, the actual number of players is bigger than what SteamDB shows.

[h2] Single Player Content [/h2]
There's Story Mode, Arcade Mode, and Survival Mode (where you get random power-up bonuses every 5 rounds). Thatâ€™s already enough for a proper single-player experience.

Is the story only for Granblue Fantasy fans? Not really. Newcomers can still enjoy it because the game includes glossaries and character bios. The cast is lovable enough that you wonâ€™t feel alienated or lost.

[h2] Art Style & Soundtrack [/h2]
The art direction is chefâ€™s kiss ðŸ¤Œ and the soundtrack goes hard. Every character has a theme that fits their personality and vibe, and almost all of them are bangers.

[h2] Price & Monetization [/h2]
I suggest to grab the Deluxe Edition when itâ€™s on sale (usually around 60% off). Youâ€™ll get the base game plus Deluxe Character Pass 1, which already unlocks about 87% of the roster. Most of the other DLC aside from Character Pass 2 â€” are cosmetics only and is purely optional.

There is also seasonal Battle Pass, which also unlocks more cosmetics contents. [b] Do note that with recent updates, some battle pass exclusives item (costumes, weapon skins, exclusive colors) will be sold as separate DLC at later date. [/b] So less FOMO contents I guess?

If youâ€™re still unsure, thereâ€™s also a free-to-play version. It limits you to 4 rotating characters and locks most modes outside of online lobbies, but itâ€™s enough to test the waters.

[h2] Overall [/h2]
This game is fun for both casual players and competitive ones. Like I said earlier, every character is charming in their own way, so youâ€™ll definitely find someone to love â€” whether thatâ€™s for their design, gameplay, personality, or the whole package.

[b] Now go give Cygames your money so we can get Season 3! [/b]

I love fighting games. I'm not great at them, but I love them. This was a title I always put off on the back shelf and never bought. I regret that I waited so long now after playing it, but I will say that I got the deluxe edition on sale, which is a fantastic value for what you get for that price. I would recommend getting it on that sale, with that edition, as you get a jump start with a lot of the extra content.

Speaking of the extra content that you could pay money for, you don't have to buy anything. If you're invested enough to put the time in, you can buy the costumes, character colors, and even the DLC characters with an in game currency called ruppee I believe it was. You can gain these by completing daily and weekly missions. When you start, you will have a nice handful to spend. I would find your character, deck them out a little bit, and go from there. I wish a lot more games did this, allow you to pay with your wallet, or your time, because both are valuable. I really like that and the game gets huge points for it.

This is a pro and a con for me, but the battle system is fairly simple with the basic short auto combo that leads to options. I get that it's easy to get into for beginners, but i've always hated mashing the same button for little auto combos. I much prefer chaining attacks from light, to medium, to heavy ect. But it is fun, and it does work well. You get a dash in attack with light, medium, and heavy, and when you've closed the gap, and are in their face, then the auto combo system takes effect, generally 3 hits with whatever given button, and properties of those attacks changing slightly dependent upon which you pushed. If you push forward and medium, your third hit will be a low, forward and heavy will be a overhead. This is the foundation upon which you will chain moves and find combos. It's simple, and effective, just slightly limited and repetitive. 

The characters play very different from one another, and the roster is quite sizable, and very enjoyable. One of the reasons I put this game on the back burner for so long is that I always kind of felt the characters were over designed, but the more I played, the more it felt just right. The character models and animations are drop dead gorgeous to look at. The super animations are fantastic, exciting, and have a lot of impact and weight. I think the intro and outro animations are spot on perfect. Your intro animation changes dependent of if you are on the player one or two side, with unique dialog between all characters dependent upon which side you started on. And you have two outro animations, your first if you win without using your ultimate super, and the other plays if you did win with your ultimate. Always love games that do this, and take full advantage of the voice actors, which all do a great job here, both in japanese, and in english. 

There are enough modes to keep me statisfied, but I do wish story mode let you spend time with other characters, and I do wish Arcade mode at least gave you proper character endings. It does not and that is always a huge let down to me. 

All and all though I would whole heartedly recommend this fighting game to anybody. It's a joy to play with responsive controls and dripping with style and quality. It's pretty simple, but fast paced, fun, and it does take skill. It has a great training mode to get you into the mechanics on offer. If I remember right, at the time of this review, the deluxe edition is on sale until Oct. 20th 2025, and I would say, if it's been sitting on your wishlist for a while now like it was on mine, now is the time to grab it.

[h2]Pros[/h2]

[h3]
[list]
[*]Unique grounded gameplay, the closest you'll get to street fighter with a true "anime style" that is still active.

[*]Decent netcode.

[*]Very easy and approachable controls, If you're looking to get into the genre, I def recommend this as your first fighting game.

[*]Free version of the game exists for you try out a character rotation. Picking up new characters in this game is generally easy.

[*]Still actively maintained and new content is released periodically, some of it accessible for free behind a grindwall.

[*]The characters are all either hot, cute, or unique and fun.

[*]Many unique and cool outfits and other char customization.

[*]Banger Music.

[*]Runs on a medium power potato (Update: support for winows 10 is being removed, so this might not hold true for long).
[/list]
[/h3]

[h2]Cons[/h2]

[h3]
[list]
[*]Matchmaker is either set to regional or GLOBAL. If you live in a deserted region prepare to get matched with chinese players.

[*]Waiting in ranked queue is generally bothersome, as the game doesn't notify you that a player has been found if tabbed out.

[*]There is no unranked queue, only rizzing up other people's avatars in the public lobby.

[*]Not much content besides ranked, room matchmaking and fall guys (grand bruise).

[*]ELO is character based, prepare to face smurfs and not be able to swap characters in ranked.
[/list]
[/h3]

If you're too braindead to make proper matchmaking, then just don't make an online pvp game.  It's the year 2025, this isn't a difficult concept.  The devs should step in a boxing ring with a professional ufc fighter.  Don't worry the ufc fighter doesn't really know the buttons for boxing so you're both "beginners" and at the "same skill level".  

The game is actually good in general and I'm sure if you have 5k hours in fighting games then what I say here doesn't apply, but the matchmaking is just so horrendous for anyone remotely new that the rest of the game doesn't matter.  Other critiques I would give, that are generally applicable to most fighting games, is that the game doesn't make clear many aspects of characters kits.  You are force to go to 3p forums, find the character, scroll down to the 8th page, read the 3rd paragraph describing the skill, to find out how to counter play it.  Now people will say some dumb crap like, just figure it out yourself by wasting 15 minutes in training mode trying every option.  Firstly, what a waste of time to do this for all the knowledge check bs for every character.  Second, go try that yourself.  The game literally won't let you even run training mode against DLC characters unless you buy them.  Good shit.

Accidentally left the game running and couldn't refund. Once I found out how simple the combo system I was done. Not enough attack diversity or control over types of attacks. Some mobile fighters have more to offer than this beautiful hot trash because it is beautiful, but this game is the definition of settling for less when you have the opportunity to do so much more.

Them putting Galleon instead of Fediel into the game shows a lack of vision.
I can't even imagine a scenario where that would be a rational choice. I think they know that gamers would be afraid of a confident tall women and instead opted out and choose a small sub-m1ss1ve women like Galleon.
Fatal choice.
I will change my review if they make the right choice and bring Fediel in.
If Lu Woh gets into the game I will crash out
Game keeps matching me with B-ranks, when I'm a new D-rank.
belial is really scary
